questions.text: When starting a new project, what excites you most?

options.text: Connecting with people who can help make it happen
Ensuring all details are perfectly organized
Sensing the right timing to launch

questions.text: In a team setting, you naturally:

options.text: Focus on systems and efficient processes
Maintain stability and support the team

questions.text: What's your biggest challenge with money?
In your ideal workday, you spend most time:

dynamo.name: Dynamo Genius
dynamo.description: You're naturally creative and innovative, seeing possibilities others miss. Like Richard Branson and Steve Jobs, you excel at starting things but may struggle with finishing details.

plan.title: Create a Completion System
plan.details: A Completion System ensures you follow through on your brilliant ideas. To create one: 1) Identify a Steel or Tempo genius in your network who excels at details and timing. 2) Schedule weekly 30-minute accountability sessions where you report progress. 3) Use a shared dashboard (like Notion or Trello) where they can see your milestones. 4) Set consequences for missed deadlines (e.g., donating to a cause you dislike). 5) Reward yourself for completed projects to reinforce the behavior.

plan.title: Set Innovation Time
plan.details: Protect your creative energy by blocking 2-3 hours daily for uninterrupted innovation. To implement: 1) Choose your peak creative time (morning for most dynamos). 2) Put this time in your calendar as a non-negotiable meeting. 3) Turn off all notifications and devices. 4) Have a dedicated space with your creative tools. 5) Start each session with a 10-minute free-writing exercise to unlock ideas. 6) End by documenting your top 3 ideas for later development.

plan.title: Implement the 3-Day Rule
plan.details: Prevent distraction by waiting 3 days before acting on new ideas. To implement: 1) Create an 'Idea Parking Lot' (physical notebook or digital app). 2) When a new idea strikes, document it immediately with date and initial excitement level (1-10). 3) Set a calendar reminder for 3 days later. 4) Re-evaluate the idea: Does it still excite you? Does it align with current goals? 5) Only pursue ideas that maintain high excitement and alignment.

plan.title: Build a Dynamo Dashboard
plan.details: Track only 3 key metrics for each project to avoid overwhelm. To create: 1) Choose metrics that measure progress toward your vision (e.g., 'Prototype completed' rather than 'Hours worked'). 2) Use a visual dashboard (like Geckoboard or a simple whiteboard). 3) Update metrics weekly at the same time. 4) Set thresholds for each metric that trigger action. 5) Review monthly with your accountability partner to ensure you're focusing on what truly matters.

plan.title: Create a Not-To-Do List
plan.details: Identify tasks that drain your energy and delegate them. To implement: 1) Track all activities for one week and note energy levels (high/medium/low). 2) Identify recurring low-energy tasks. 3) For each task: Can it be automated? Delegated? Eliminated? 4) Create a formal Not-To-Do list with these tasks. 5) Review quarterly and add new energy-draining tasks. 6) Use the reclaimed time for high-energy, high-impact activities.

blaze.name: Blaze Genius
blaze.description: You're a natural connector and communicator, building relationships effortlessly. Like Oprah Winfrey and Bill Clinton, you magnify opportunities through people but may overlook details.

plan.title: Create a Relationship Map
plan.details: Identify 20 key relationships to nurture quarterly. To create: 1) List everyone in your network by category (mentors, peers, mentees, connectors). 2) Rate each relationship by value (1-10) and current engagement (high/medium/low). 3) Select top 20 across categories. 4) For each, note: their goals, how you can help, and how they can help you. 5) Schedule quarterly check-ins with each. 6) Use a CRM like HubSpot or even a spreadsheet to track interactions.

plan.title: Implement Focus Fridays
plan.details: Dedicate one day weekly to deep work without meetings. To implement: 1) Block your entire Friday calendar as 'Focus Time'. 2) Choose 1-2 important projects requiring deep thinking. 3) Prepare Thursday evening: clear workspace, gather materials, set specific goals. 4) Turn off all notifications and social media. 5) Work in 90-minute focused sprints with 30-minute breaks. 6) End day by reviewing progress and planning next week's focus.

plan.title: Build a Blaze Brief
plan.details: Create templates for routine communications to save time. To implement: 1) Identify recurring communications (emails, proposals, updates). 2) For each, create a template with: purpose, key points, call to action. 3) Include placeholders for personalization (name, specific details). 4) Store templates in an accessible system (email templates, document library). 5) Review and update templates quarterly based on feedback. 6) Track time saved to reinforce the habit.

plan.title: Partner with a Steel Genius
plan.details: Have them handle data and systems. To implement: 1) Identify Steel geniuses in your network (they love details and systems). 2) Propose a mutual support partnership: you handle relationships, they handle data. 3) Define clear boundaries: what they'll analyze, what decisions you'll make together. 4) Schedule regular syncs to review their analysis. 5) Compensate them fairly (money, introductions, reciprocal help). 6) Celebrate wins together to strengthen the partnership.

plan.title: Practice the 1-3-5 Rule
plan.details: Daily, achieve 1 big, 3 medium, and 5 small tasks. To implement: 1) Each evening, list all tasks for tomorrow. 2) Categorize by size/impact: Big (2+ hours, high impact), Medium (30-60 mins), Small (under 30 mins). 3) Select 1 Big, 3 Medium, 5 Small tasks that align with your goals. 4) Schedule them in your calendar with time blocks. 5) Start with the Big task when energy is highest. 6) At day's end, review completion and adjust tomorrow's list.

tempo.name: Tempo Genius
tempo.description: You're grounded and intuitive, with excellent timing and perseverance. Like Warren Buffett and Mother Teresa, you create value through perfect timing but may resist change.

plan.title: Create a Tempo Trigger
plan.details: Establish a clear signal for when to act on opportunities. To create: 1) Identify your best past decisions: what signals were present? 2) Define 3-5 specific triggers (e.g., market conditions, personal readiness, resource availability). 3) Assign a point value to each trigger. 4) Set a threshold (e.g., 8/10 points) for taking action. 5) Create a decision checklist to verify triggers. 6) Practice with low-stakes decisions to refine your trigger system.

plan.title: Implement Innovation Partnerships
plan.details: Collaborate with Dynamo geniuses. To implement: 1) Identify Dynamo geniuses who complement your stability. 2) Propose structured collaborations: you provide timing/stability, they provide innovation. 3) Define clear roles: who ideates, who evaluates, who executes. 4) Set regular brainstorming sessions with your Tempo insights as foundation. 5) Create a shared innovation pipeline to track ideas. 6) Celebrate both successes and learning experiences to strengthen the partnership.

plan.title: Build a Tempo Tracker
plan.details: Monitor market rhythms and personal energy cycles. To create: 1) Track key market indicators relevant to your field. 2) Monitor your personal energy levels throughout the day (1-10 scale). 3) Note when you make good decisions: what was your energy? market conditions? 4) Identify patterns: when are you most intuitive? when is the market most receptive? 5) Schedule important decisions during your peak Tempo times. 6) Review monthly to refine your understanding of your natural rhythms.

plan.title: Practice Strategic Risk
plan.details: Take 1 small calculated risk monthly. To implement: 1) Define 'small risk' for you (e.g., 5% of resources, 1 day of time). 2) Create a risk assessment template: potential upside, downside, mitigation strategies. 3) Each month, identify 3 potential risks meeting your criteria. 4) Select one with best risk-reward ratio. 5) Execute with clear success metrics. 6) Afterward, conduct a 'risk review': what worked? what didn't? what did you learn?

plan.title: Create a Growth Ritual
plan.details: Spend 30 minutes daily learning something new. To implement: 1) Choose a consistent time (morning works best for most). 2) Select diverse learning sources: books, podcasts, courses, mentors. 3) Create a learning plan: 1 month per new topic. 4) During your ritual: consume new information for 20 mins, then reflect for 10 mins. 5) Keep a learning journal: key insights, how to apply, connections to existing knowledge. 6) Monthly, review journal entries and identify patterns to guide future learning.

steel.name: Steel Genius
steel.description: You're detail-oriented and systematic, creating order from chaos. Like Mark Zuckerberg and Ray Kroc, you build efficient systems but may struggle with people connections.

plan.title: Create a Steel System
plan.details: Document all processes in a central manual. To implement: 1) Identify all recurring tasks in your work/life. 2) For each, document: purpose, steps, tools, time required, quality standards. 3) Use a consistent format (checklists work well). 4) Store in a central, searchable location (Notion, Confluence, or physical binder). 5) Review and update systems quarterly. 6) Create a 'System Index' to quickly find the right process for any situation.

plan.title: Implement People Time
plan.details: Schedule 3 short social interactions daily. To implement: 1) Block 15-minute slots in your calendar for 'Connection Time'. 2) Prepare 2-3 conversation starters related to current projects or interests. 3) Reach out to different people each day: colleagues, clients, mentors. 4) During interactions: focus on listening, ask open questions, find common ground. 5) Afterward, note 1 key insight from the conversation. 6) Weekly, review these insights to identify patterns and opportunities.

plan.title: Build a Delegation Dashboard
plan.details: Identify tasks only you should do. To create: 1) List all your regular tasks. 2) For each, ask: Does this require my unique skills? Could someone else do it 80% as well? 3) Categorize tasks: Core (only you), Important (delegate with oversight), Routine (fully delegate). 4) For Important tasks: create clear instructions and success metrics. 5) For Routine tasks: document processes and train others. 6) Track time saved and reinvest it in high-value Core tasks.

plan.title: Partner with a Blaze Genius
plan.details: Have them handle relationships and communication. To implement: 1) Identify Blaze geniuses who complement your systems focus. 2) Propose a mutual support partnership: you handle systems, they handle relationships. 3) Define which communications they'll own (client updates, team motivation). 4) Provide them with clear data points to inform their communications. 5) Schedule brief syncs to align on messaging. 6) Measure the impact: improved relationships, team morale, client satisfaction.

plan.title: Practice Visionary Hour
plan.details: Weekly, spend 60 minutes on big-picture thinking. To implement: 1) Choose a consistent time (Friday afternoons work well). 2) Remove yourself from your usual workspace. 3) Bring only a journal and pen (no devices). 4) Ask: Where is this heading in 5 years? What's missing? What should we stop/start? 5. Capture all ideas without judgment. 6) Afterward, categorize ideas: immediate actions, future considerations, wild possibilities. 7) Share insights with your team or mentor.
